author: InvisibleTimmy
title: “It was opened?” “Just a smidge.”
review:
Box and Instructions

The box is of normal size for a 300 or so piece set. The instructions came bent.

Minifigure 

The one minifigure in the set is Newt Scamander. Every part of him is unique: Head, hair, torso, legs, and game pad base. Unfortunately, he doesn't come with his suitcase. Just a fair warning.

Build

The build is basic. The Niffler, as is the norm, has no paper instructions. MACUSA doorway, however, does have instructions. Although just a facade, it does have some good depth.The lifts are excellently done. 

Parts

These parts are exclusive:

2x3 pentagonal tile, reddish brown

2x2 round tile, macusa print, pearl gold

3x3 game base, trans yellow, Newt Scamander print

Claw, dark flesh

These are rare:

2x2 life ring, reddish brown

Story pack baseplate, dark bluish grey

1x1 round tile, transparent black

1x1 round plate with bar, dark flesh

Completed Model

The Niffler is quite cute. Its snout can be posed to look like it’s just been sniffing out some treasure, a pile of which it sits upon. It also has some gold round plates in its pouch to represent shiny things it’s stolen.

The MACUSA doorway is aesthetically very pleasing. The  build is quite accurate to the film, with the MACUSA logo just above the door. The doors and the back of the lifts are made with the Elves fence. The lifts themselves are simple but look good, with accurate gold grating on the wall.

Playability

The in game playability is obviously quite high, given its Story Pack designation. I don’t own the game, so that’s all I’m gonna say.

The MACUSA Model does have some simple play features. The doors can open, and the lifts can be elevated with a basic Technic mechanism that automatically locks it in place. This actually has practical use, because it frees up two spaces for game figures under the lifts, in addition to the ones on the lifts.

Overall

This is a fun little set. The price isn’t that bad if you consider that you’re getting $20 of game and $2 0of LEGO , but if you don’t own the game, wait for a discount (I got mine at Best Buy for only $10 USD). All in all, get it now while it’s cheap.

author: Ephseb
title: A Dimensions Movie Pack, reviewed by a non-Dimensions-player
review:
Why did I even buy this?

Well, the Dimensions sets apparently never sold all that well here in Vienna, so all the Toy-and-Videogame-stores still have some packs from 3 years ago rotting on their shelves at retail price. However, since November of 2017, one chain offers a discount of 25% on all Dimensions sets. This week, I saw that those Dimensions sets that were still left had been discounted even further, by 66% (Fun Packs) and 60% (Movie Packs), with an additional discount of 25% on all Lego items. Since the other Lego sets weren't that interesting to me, I bought 4 Fun Packs (15€ total) and 3 copies of this Set, Fantastic Beasts: Play The Movie (45€ total).

Box/Instructions

The box is very reasonably sized in relation to the amount of pieces and the final build. Not much else is new..

Parts

This set really shines here. Several rare brown parts, including the 2x3 flat Shield-shaped plate, lifesavers, and two long plates, are included. The dark grey plate with a 6x6 circular hole, as well as the fences, wings and small clips in gold are also an excellent addition to any collection. The MACUSA Sigil is printed on a 2x2 circular golden plate, and is already a favorite of mine. The Sigil, and the head and body of Scamander are all exclusive to this set, and I imagine you could build a larger (maybe Modular Building-sized) MACUSA using this set and its concepts as a starting point.

Minifigures

Only one here, Newt Scamander, who looks true to Mr. Redmayne in the movie, and has some great printing on both the torso and the legs. He comes with a brown wand.

I don't think I'm alone when I express my opinion that the inclusion more Minifigs would certainly have made this set more attractive. If it had been up to me, I would've put Percival Graves and/or Seraphina Pickery(?), the US equivalent to the minister of magic, into this set alongside Newt.

The build

Pretty nice, took me less than 20 minutes. It's annoying that the instructions for the Niffler are in the game and not in the booklet with the rest of the build, but it's a nice challenge to try and build the animal with only the picture on the box as reference. If the golden wings on the main door aren't aligned properly, the door can't be closed, so you need to watch out for that.

The completed model

It's a nice display piece. If you want to play with it, you'll probably have to expand it with bricks and plates from your collection. For now, you can move the two elevators up and down, and open/close the golden door. I will keep one built for now, but add the parts from the other 2 to my ever-growing stock of Lego. The Niffler is well-designed (All important aspects of the animal are included, among them the snout, the claws and the poach), even if it's not to scale with the minifig.

Overall opinion

Using the Technic pieces to lift the elevators is a great idea, and implemented well. Now you need to build a second floor...

If you don't have this yet, and want to get it, I'd recommend to go for it if you can find it for 25€ or lower. The RRP of 50€ is extremely hard to justify. Depending on whether you own the Dimensions videogame and want this set for its intended purpose - to "Play The Movie" - the amount of money you're willing to spend may vary.

I guess that the whole concept of "Expansion Packs" (equivalent to DLC) for Lego Dimensions played a part in its poor sales (at least judging from the always-full shelves before Fall 2017), as next to no-one was willing to pay 100€ for the main game and then around 90€ for every wave of Packs.

 

(Note: I always base the "value for money" points on the regular retail price, not the amount of money I ended up paying.)

author: Odeinoichus
title: Visit the Wizarding World in the Past.
review:
Set #71253 Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them Story Pack: The Wizarding World returns to LEGO in time for a new Media Franchise to add more characters and set pieces to your LEGO Harry Potter collection. Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them was the catalyst for a return of Harry Potter to the LEGO universe. And what better place to showcase it than here, in LEGO Dimensions.

Packaging

Box: Sharing a packaging design with the previous Story Pack this box works well and stands out on the shelf with Newt, the Niffler and MACUSA clearly shown on the front and back so you can differentiate it from the similar coloured boxes of Ghostbusters and LEGO Batman on the shelf.

Instructions: This manual is the same as all of the rest in these boxed sets, it shows not only other sets you can collect in the Theme via checklists in the back, but includes all of the steps necessary to build the Gateway Add-On model for MACUSA. A very enjoyable model to follow along with while building, the steps are easy and the parts use superb.

Parts

This set is loaded with a lot of excellent reddish brown elements and some pearl gold parts as well. Mostly fences and doorway elements, but the parts are there. You get a lot of value for your money and while the reddish brown bricks seem to have some kind of inherent design flaw, as discussed in the Forum, to see so many of them here is a welcome idea.

Minifigures

Newt Scamander: The Dimensions version of Newt has a unique print compared to the one found in the Collectible Minifigures Set, while they share the same outfit design, Dimensions Newt doesn’t have his little green friend in his pocket and seems to have slightly subdued colours. He also is using the older LEGO bar piece for a wand as the new wand element had not yet been invented. (Fortunately due to the nature of those pieces you can choose to give this Newt his actual wand from the spare in the CMF line if you so wish.)

Overall a very good Minifigure and a nice unique Toy Tag design for the character.

The build

MACUSA: The build for the Gateway add-on element to replace the Portal or the Ghostbusters Gateway is just as involved and engaging as you would expect. It’s a very part heavy build with a lot of steps and as you make it you come to find that you are building a fairly expansive item to attach to your Gateway. I found this one to be just as impressive as the one discussed previously in the Ghostbusters Story Pack.

Niffler: This build is extremely solid and I am quite a fan of it. The steps were fun and the end product a real treat to see completed.

Sinister Scorpion: This is a very weak and pitiful attempt to build something else out of the parts. I found this build to be rather poorly executed, compared to the digital in-game model it just lacks presence and you see that with each step of the build.

Vicious Vulture: An equally weak build that could have used more forethought in my opinion, I like the ideas implemented here a bit better, building the wings works, but it is clear that the parts used on the Niffler had the designers struggling to find decent animals to make out of them after they solved how to make the primary model.

The completed model

MACUSA: This model is again, very impressive, with some actual moving parts. Two lifts on the side can raise and lower, on top of that it is rather wide. But the best aspect of this Gateway model is the fact that you can store more than seven Toys on the Toy Pad when it is attached. While only seven of them can actually be used at one time, the extra lifts on the side of the Gateway allow you to put two more Toy Tags off to the side for quick and easy access and storage of your LEGO Dimensions toys.

This model can also open and close the door and features two Technic based play features to raise and lower the two Lifts on the side. An overall very well designed and functional model compared to some of the others we have for the Toy Pad.

Niffler & Alternate Models: This serves as a very nice brick-built version of the iconic little creature from the two films. It uses parts to great effect. The other two models you can rebuild out of these parts however are somewhat weaker. The Sinister Scorpion is anything but, winding up far too cute and oddly proportioned to be anything truly sinister, and the Vicious Vulture is purely a joke. Neither alternate model matches up very closely with the digital counterparts.

The Digital Content

Story Levels: Once again you are going to be playing through six levels representing six key moments of the original film. These levels range in length and enjoyment with the first level originally having a very bad game breaking glitch late in the game, once you make it to the second area of the first level it had the bad tendency to freeze or pause up, mostly when trying to use the Sword Switch to solve one of the puzzles for a Minikit piece.

This was the only really glaring issue I had with the levels as the rest of them worked as intended without any frame drops, character glitches or locking folks off from accessing areas you are meant to go to. Overall I enjoyed all six levels despite the initial problems I had and the rest worked smoothly.

Battle Arena: The Fantastic Beasts Arid Animal Habitat is where you and four friends/family members can visit to duke it out in Multiplayer Competitions. Again, I haven’t much to say about this aspect of the game, but I find that these Arenas are at least all fairly unique and interesting, with possibly one or two exceptions. I believe this Arena represents somewhere inside Newt’s case, but I could be wrong about that.

Adventure World: The Adventure World for Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them is another representation of New York City, specifically the one found in the late 1930’s early 1940’s shown in the film. This makes a grand total of three separate Adventure Worlds you can visit of New York, here and both versions of the Ghostbuster’s New York. It’s interesting to see different interpretations of familiar landmarks though, so there is that going for it.

Character & Vehicle Abilities: Newt is, of course, a Wizard, and as a Wizard he shares similar abilities with other Wizards. He can Destroy Silver LEGO Objects, use Magic, Fix-It, Intelligence, Stealth, Targets, Laser Deflector and Water Spray. Unique to Wizarding World Wizards are the Diffindo spell, the Apparate Access and his Fantastical Briefcase ability which is only used a very minimum number of times.

The Niffler is a Playable Character, meaning that you don’t ride it, but can switch to using it as if it were a regular character on a Toy Tag. It can Dig and has both the Guardian Ability and an Enhanced Stud Attraction which allows you to collect studs from further away. Similar to the Magnet Unlocks of previous LEGO Games. (Or Attract Studs if you prefer.)

The Sinister Scorpion alternate build can use Vine Cut and has a Special Weapon on top of the Guardian Ability. The final build, Vicious Vulture, adds the ability to Destroy Gold LEGO Objects to the mix, but has very little else in the way of abilities.

Overall opinion

As I noted in the previous Story Pack Review, if you want to experience everything on The Shard, purchasing this set is mandatory. So I strongly recommend tracking it down if you skipped it initially. I found this experience to be relatively enjoyable overall, with very little problems or frustrating game play elements and the physical models and Minifigure look great and add a lot. I do feel that the Niffler is the best of the three creature builds though, and feel the others are somewhat superfluous.

Strongly Recommended.

author: Puidwen
title: An very enjoyable set
review: Another dimensions set i got for the aesthetics .  Since these sets are mean just to hold figures for the games i'm impressed with how many features Lego has given them.  It was a much more enjoyable building experience then 71242-1.  The only problem i had is one of the doors just didn't want to snap.  When you open it up you notice that there is a lot of technic pieces in it.  The niffler is cute.  I consider just leaving him off the base like i did Ecto-1 but i found he stands and looks better on it.
